question: In mice, does preexisting infection with the intestinal helminth Nippostrongylus brasiliensis impair immune control of Mycobacterium tuberculosis coinfection—raising pulmonary bacterial burden via IL-4Rα–dependent alternative macrophage activation? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: We show that mice infected with the intestinal helminth Nippostrongylus brasiliensis (Nb) exhibit a transitory impairment of resistance to airborne Mtb infection.
content.source_2: In a repeated-exposure protocol, a booster Nb inoculation prior to Mtb challenge attenuated pulmonary bacillary loads, yielding fewer CFU than in mice experiencing a single Nb infection.
content.source_3: The Th2 response can thus enhance the intracellular persistence of Mtb, in part by mediating the alternative activation of macrophages via the IL-4Rα signaling pathway.
content.source_4: Contrary to a Th2-mediated effect, macrophages from helminth–Mtb coinfected animals displayed classical activation signatures and improved bacterial killing, and these outcomes were unchanged by IL-4Rα blockade.
